Literature Review: The development of sustainable polymers from biological matter has gained significant attention in recent years due to the urgent need for renewable alternatives to traditional petroleum-based materials. This literature review aims to explore the progress made in this field, focusing on the extraction and utilization of bioderived monomers and polymers, as well as the emergence of polymers produced directly from unprocessed biomatter.One of the primary drivers for sustainable polymer research is the increasing global concern over environmental issues and resource depletion. Mohanty et al. (2018) highlighted the importance of transitioning from petrochemical-based polymers to bio-based alternatives, emphasizing the potential for reduced carbon footprint and enhanced biodegradability. Their comprehensive review of bio-based polymers provided insights into the various sources of biomatter and their potential applications in different industries.The extraction and utilization of bioderived monomers and polymers have been a focal point of sustainable polymer research. Gandini and Lacerda (2015) explored the use of furan-based monomers derived from renewable resources for the synthesis of novel polymers. Their work demonstrated the versatility of these monomers in producing materials with properties comparable to their petroleum-based counterparts. Similarly, Llevot et al. (2016) investigated the potential of lignin-derived monomers for the development of sustainable polymers, highlighting the abundance of lignin as a renewable resource and its potential to replace aromatic petroleum-based monomers.In recent years, there has been growing interest in polymers produced directly from unprocessed biomatter. Nguyen et al. (2019) reported on the development of bioplastics derived from whole algal biomass, showcasing the potential of using entire microorganisms as a source of sustainable materials. This approach eliminates the need for extensive processing and extraction steps, potentially reducing the overall environmental impact of polymer production.The application of sustainable polymers in various fields has been extensively studied. In the realm of bioplastics, Reddy et al. (2013) provided a comprehensive review of polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs), a class of biodegradable polyesters produced by microorganisms. Their work highlighted the potential of PHAs as alternatives to conventional plastics in packaging and biomedical applications. The development of biocomposites has also gained traction, with Thakur et al. (2014) exploring the use of natural fibers as reinforcements in polymer matrices. Their research demonstrated the potential of biocomposites to achieve mechanical properties comparable to traditional composites while offering improved environmental sustainability.Cementitious biomaterials represent another promising application area for sustainable polymers. Pacheco-Torgal and Jalali (2011) investigated the use of bio-based admixtures in concrete, demonstrating their potential to enhance mechanical properties and durability while reducing the environmental impact of construction materials. This research highlights the interdisciplinary nature of sustainable polymer development and its potential to revolutionize multiple industries.Understanding the fundamental mechanisms underlying the performance of sustainable polymers is crucial for their successful implementation. Zhu et al. (2016) conducted a detailed study on the structure-property relationships of bio-based polymers, providing valuable insights into the molecular-level interactions that govern their macroscopic properties. This knowledge is essential for designing sustainable materials with tailored properties for specific applications.As the field of sustainable polymers continues to advance, there is a growing need for accurate and accessible tools to assess their life-cycle impacts. Hottle et al. (2013) conducted a critical review of life cycle assessment (LCA) methodologies for biopolymers, highlighting the challenges and limitations of current approaches. Their work emphasized the importance of developing standardized LCA methods to enable fair comparisons between traditional and bio-based materials.The socioeconomic challenges associated with the transition to sustainable polymers cannot be overlooked. Iles and Martin (2013) examined the policy and market barriers to the widespread adoption of bio-based materials, emphasizing the need for supportive regulatory frameworks and consumer education to drive market acceptance.In conclusion, the development of sustainable polymers from biological matter has made significant strides in recent years, with promising advances in the extraction and utilization of bioderived monomers and polymers, as well as the emergence of materials produced directly from unprocessed biomatter. Applications in bioplastics, biocomposites, and cementitious materials demonstrate the versatility and potential of these sustainable alternatives. However, challenges remain in accurately assessing life-cycle impacts and addressing socioeconomic barriers to widespread adoption. Future research should focus on refining production processes, improving material properties, and developing standardized assessment tools to facilitate the transition towards a more sustainable materials economy.
